stem: The nurse is reviewing life-span screenings for four female clients at a community health fair. Based on the documentation, match each client with the most appropriate priority screening intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 21-year-old female. Never had a pelvic exam.
Patient B: 30-year-old female. Last Pap smear was 3 years ago (Normal).
Patient C: 46-year-old female. Has never had a colonoscopy.
Patient D: 65-year-old female. History of osteoporosis and tobacco use.

tabs.title: Preventative Screening Matrix
tabs.content:
PatientAgeLast ScreenAction to Take
A21NeverFirst Pap (cytology)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: All patients are asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable.

rows.text: Cervical cancer screening (Pap test) every 3 years
Pap test + HPV co-testing every 5 years

rationale.correct: Cervical cancer screening starts at 21 with Pap cytology alone every 3 years (Patient A). At age 30, the preference shifts to co-testing with HPV every 5 years (Patient B). The USPSTF now recommends average-risk colonoscopy starting at age 45 (Patient C). Women 65 and older should receive a baseline DEXA scan to screen for osteoporosis (Patient D).
clinicalPearls: Pap smears do NOT depend on when the patient first had intercourse (always start at 21).
Colonoscopy age was lowered from 50 to 45 in recent NCLEX updates.
Cervical screening usually ends at age 65 if previous tests were consistently normal.

questionTrap.trap: Believing Pap smears should start at age 18 if the patient is sexually active.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NCLEX follows the rule: 21 is the magic number for cervical screening start.
